awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Experimental and theoretical characterization of rapid Jurassic true polar wander
awd_abstract_narration:
The motion of continents throughout the geologic history of the Earth strongly affects a vast number of processes on its surface. Among the effects of continental drift are the formation of mountain belts and volcanoes, the spread and extinction of biodiversity, and changes in climate at the local and global scales. Continents on Earth may move via one of two fundamentally different processes. The more familiar mechanism, known as plate tectonics, involves the differential motion of continents relative to each other. The second, less well-understood process is known as true polar wander (TPW), wherein the entire Earth rotates as a single unit such that the location of the present pole is transferred to a lower latitude. Theoretical studies show that TPW should have strong effects on the global environment, including regional sea-level changes of >100 m and drift of land surface across multiple, contrasting climate zones. However, the cause, rate, and even the existence of large-scale TPW events in Earth history have been controversial. Here we will measure the magnetism of rocks from the Late Jurassic (~165-150 million years before present) and pursue theoretical geodynamical computations to characterize the motion of the Earth during this most recent proposed episode of TPW. The results will have important implications for understanding the drivers of observed sea-level and climate changes throughout geologic time and for elucidating a fundamental process by which the global geography of the Earth evolves.

This project is divided into two closely coupled parts that use complementary techniques to understand Jurassic TPW. First, the investigators will collect paleomagnetic rock samples from the La Negra Formation of Northern Chile and the Chon Aike province of Patagonian Argentina to quantify the position of continents during the 165-150 million year ago (Ma) interval, which has been identified by previous studies as the most recent time interval of potentially large amplitude (about 30 degrees) TPW. These rock units represent the most continuous deposits of igneous rocks from the candidate TPW interval, which implies the highest likelihood of recovering high precision paleogeographical information using paleomagnetic techniques. As part of this experimental component of this project, the team will collect samples for geochronological analysis using Ar-Ar and U-Pb in zircon techniques, which would provide more reliable rates of motion during this time span. Second, they will simulate the polar wander of the Earth using existing geodynamical code that accounts for the motion of mass anomalies in the mantle and lateral variations in the lithospheric strength of the Earth. A second, coupled geodynamical code will compute the expected changes in regional sea-level caused by the TPW motion. Combined with experimental data, these models will narrow the range of possible drivers of Late Jurassic TPW and evaluate its potential effect on records of climate and sea-level.

por.por_cntn:
The Earth's surface is divided into a number of mobile tectonic plates.  These plates can move across the Earth's surface in one of two ways.  The more familiar type of motion, also called plate tectonics, is movement among plates, accommodated by mid-ocean ridges and subduction zones.  A lesser understood mode of motion is true polar wander, or TPW.  In this process the entire mantle and crust of the Earth move in unison around an equatorial rotation axis.  Although reported to have occurred during several short but intense intervals in Earth history, robust quantitative confirmation of TPW and its rate of motion remains controversial.

This project set out to discover whether rapid TPW occurred during the late Jurassic Period, about 160-145 million years ago (Ma).  We first sought to confirm whether observed plate motion at ~150 Ma indeed included the entire Earth’s surface.  Previous work used only continental rocks as data, even though oceanic plates make up most of the Earth’s surface.  Our paleomagnetic re-study of a drill core from the western Pacific Ocean collected in 1992 showed that, indeed, the Pacific Plate and its associated oceanic plates underwent anomalous motion between 160 and 145 Ma, confirming that this motion was TPW instead of coincidentally coherent motion of several plates (Fu and Kent 2018, Earth. Planet. Sci. Lett. 490).  

Once the TPW nature of motion in this time interval was established, we sampled nearly 100 individual lava flows emplaced in coastal Chile between 166 and 153 Ma.  By simultaneously pursuing argon-argon age dating and paleomagnetism on these samples, we showed that TPW proceeded at a rate of 1.21˚ per million years between 170 and 145 Ma, which is very rapid compared to typical plate velocities (Fu et al. 2020, Earth. Planet. Sci. Lett. 529).  Because these data are based on a continuous succession of igneous rocks, I believe they represent the most accurate characterization of a large-amplitude TPW event published to-date. 

Following permission from Dr. Reichlin, the program manager, we applied resources from this grant to investigate the interplay of plate tectonic motion and TPW at other times in Earth history.  After sampling a suite of rocks from the Pilbara Craton of Western Australia in 2017, our paleomagnetic studies showed that this landmass moved across the Earth’s surface with at least 2.5 cm per year velocities between 3.35 and 3.18 billion years ago (Ga) (Brenner et al. 2020, Sci. Adv. 6).  With the data available at that time, we could not confidently distinguish between a plate tectonic and TPW origin to the motion, although in either case, the result suggested a geodynamically active Earth. 

Finally, we followed up on the Brenner et al. 2020 result by performing paleomagnetic sampling, micromagnetic mineralogy analysis, and geochronological dating on another group of volcanic rocks from the Pilbara Craton.  By using the recently developed quantum diamond microscope (QDM) to directly identify the magnetized grain assemblages in the rocks and using U-Pb in titanite geochronology to date these minerals, we were able to establish that the magnetization of the rocks was acquired during aqueous alteration at 3.25 Ga.  This insight allowed us to reconstruct the motion of the Pilbara Craton over a 170-million-year interval between 3.35 and 3.18 Ga when combined with previously published results.  This analysis showed that the Pilbara Craton moved over the Earth surface with velocities of at least 6 cm per year.  Critically, the geometry of the motion during this interval shifted significantly over the full time interval, implying that TPW, which is locked to the 3D distribution of mass in the Earth, is unlikely to have been the cause.  We therefore concluded that mobile plates were actively and independently moving on the Earth by 3.25 Ga, which is at least 400-million-years earlier than previously known (Brenner et al. 2023 Proc. Nat. Acad. Sci. USA 119).  

In summary, this project funded exploration into the balance between plate motion and true polar wander throughout Earth history.  We found that on the most ancient Earth, as today, true polar wander was of secondary importance compared to independent plate motions.  Nevertheless, when it did occur, true polar wander achieved impressive velocities, motivation future studies of the poorly known mechanisms that may have triggered such periods of anomalous Earth motion. 

This grant has funded the majority of PhD student Alec Brenner work at Harvard.  It has provided an opportunity for Alec to pursue a set of extremely difficult rock samples and to develop novel combinations of techniques, including magnetic field imaging, to study them.  These developments will aid in a wide range of future studies including Alec Brenner’s own work as he continues his highly promising career.
